content: Arrays in JavaScript are ordered collections of elements. They allow storing multiple values under a single variable. You can create an array using square brackets. Example: let arr = [1, 2, 3];
You can access elements using their index (starting from 0). Use arr[index] to get or set values. Example: arr[0] = 10;
`push()` adds elements to the end of the array, while `pop()` removes the last element. Example: arr.push(4); arr.pop();
practice_que: Add a number to array, remove last number, and return the array.

content: `unshift()` adds elements to the beginning, `shift()` removes the first element. Useful for queue-based structures.
You can loop using `for`, `forEach`, or `map`. Example: arr.forEach(item => console.log(item));
`slice(start, end)` returns a portion of the array. `splice(start, deleteCount)` changes the array by removing/replacing items.
Use `includes()`, `indexOf()`, `filter()`, and `find()` to locate elements. Example: arr.filter(x => x > 5);
